    Plot Choice-Level Marginal Means (MMs)

    plot_projoint_choice_level_mm.Rd

    This function produces a plot of choice-level marginal means (MMs) given a projoint_results object, which is the output from the projoint function. It supports two types of visualizations: a bar plot and a pointrange plot.

    Usage

    plot_projoint_choice_level_mm(
  x,
  .type = "pointrange",
  .estimates = "corrected",
  .labels = NULL,
  .show_attribute = TRUE,
  .remove_xaxis = FALSE,
  .xlim = c(0, 1),
  .plot.margin = c(top = 1, left = 2, bottom = 1, right = 2),
  ...
)

    Arguments

    x

    A projoint_results object. This is the output from the projoint() function.

    .type

    Type of plot to produce. Either "bar" (default) for bar plots or "pointrange" for a horizontal point-range plot.

    .estimates

    Which estimates to plot. Options are "corrected" (default) or "uncorrected".

    .labels

    A character vector specifying custom labels for the x-axis (optional). If NULL (default), labels are automatically generated from the data.

    .show_attribute

    Logical; if TRUE (default), display the attribute name as the plot title.

    .remove_xaxis

    Logical; if TRUE, remove the x-axis elements (ticks, labels, and line). Default is FALSE.

    .xlim

    A numeric vector specifying the x-axis limits (default is c(0, 1)).

    .plot.margin

    A numeric vector specifying plot margins in centimeters, ordered as c(top, left, bottom, right). Default is c(1, 2, 1, 2). If NULL, margins are automatically set based on label lengths.

    ...

    Additional arguments (currently unused).

    Value

    A ggplot2 object.

    Details

    When .type = "pointrange", the two attribute levels are automatically positioned slightly outside the [0,1] x-axis range to avoid overlap with confidence intervals. If .labels is not supplied, the function attempts to extract level labels from the input object.

    If the two levels being compared belong to different attributes, a warning message is shown and no title is added.

    On this page

    Developed by Yusaku Horiuchi, Aaron Kaufman, Gary King.
